channel.title: What type of video card do I need?
channel.description: Well, my computer is from 2002 I've upgraded the RAM in it, and now I want to upgrade the Video card. I have a Emachine the model is [u]T2892[/u] and I prefer a Nvidia

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

Your computer is too old to be upgraded to a new graphics card. You might be able to find an AGP graphics card, but after upgrading, your old 2002 machine would probably have other components that are too slow. I recommend you get a new computer if possible.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:16, topic:214048”][quote author=davidude36 link=topic=281696.msg2288483#msg2288483 date=1214028194]
Both PCI and AGP are no longer put into motherboards.
[/quote]
My bad, Rictoo helpfully reminded me PCI slots are put into motherboards these days. But generally they are not used for graphics cards. What I should have said “Both PCI cards and AGP cards are not longer manufactured”[/quote]

exactly. You still use PCI for things like extra USB / firewire ports or sound cards. If you don’t want on-board sound, then PCI is a must.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

@davidude36 wrote:

davidude36:

Both PCI and AGP are no longer put into motherboards.

My bad, Rictoo helpfully reminded me PCI slots are put into motherboards these days. But generally they are not used for graphics cards. What I should have said “Both PCI graphics cards and AGP graphics cards are not longer manufactured”

item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

[quote=“postmanpat9, post:12, topic:214048”]@exps35, wtf does your CPU socket type have to do with your ram?

EDIT: lol realized a minute after posting this what you meant sorry lol.[/quote]

Yea, I just meant that with a newer CPU means a newer motherboard, and with a newer motherboard comes support for newer RAM technology - most currently being DDR2

a mobo still running on AGP slots won’t have 6400 slots, and an Athlon X2 / PCI-E mobo wont have 2100.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

[quote=“exps35, post:10, topic:214048”]You can’t salvage old RAM from a motherboard most of the time. Especially this instance, where he is going from an AGP (most likely) or possibly a PCI motherboard, which will have a completely different CPU slot that the new one he will need to get with a newer motherboard.

there are different types of RAM: 4200, 5200, DDR, DDR2, etc. depending on your CPU slot on the mobo.

so yea. Ideally, the only things that can be used again is possibly the sound card (if any) and a Hard Drive. Theres usually at least one IDE port on new motherboards…I think. Newer and much faster Hard drives are SATA, so it would be much more wise to invest in one.[/quote]
I know that much. I’m saying if can use it and it’s of decent quality, use it.
When I said old, I didn’t mean something that was necessarily a few years old or anything. If he just bought new RAM, and then buys new parts, I would classify the RAM as old (or at least older), etc.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

Holic:

Salvage old, but usable parts (like your RAM) and buy the rest.

You can’t salvage old RAM from a motherboard most of the time. Especially this instance, where he is going from an AGP (most likely) or possibly a PCI motherboard, which will have a completely different CPU slot that the new one he will need to get with a newer motherboard.

there are different types of RAM: 4200, 5200, DDR, DDR2, etc. depending on your CPU slot on the mobo.

so yea. Ideally, the only things that can be used again is possibly the sound card (if any) and a Hard Drive. Theres usually at least one IDE port on new motherboards…I think. Newer and much faster Hard drives are SATA, so it would be much more wise to invest in one.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Can you even buy PCI GFX cards anymore?
Just a heads up, you’ll probably need to buy a new PSU.

It’s not worth the upgrade, simpler and just plain better in the long run to get a new computer. Salvage old, but usable parts (like your RAM) and buy the rest.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Or you can look up your motherboard model and look to buy another one, usually you’ll find technical specifications.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“Payback Is A Bitch, post:5, topic:214048”][quote author=davidude36 link=topic=281696.msg2288483#msg2288483 date=1214028194]
Payback, with graphics cards you are going to need to learn that through the years motherboards have upgraded to support better graphics cards. This means that most of the high end graphics cards out today wont actually fit into your pc.

It is most likely that you motherboard is of type “AGP”. However most of todays system’s (2004+) graphics cards use a newer slot called PCI-E (pci express).

Find out what type of graphics card your motherboard takes. It’ll either be PCI or AGP, if it is PCI then I highly suggest you get a new motherboard. (PCI is not the same as earlier mentioned PCI-E). Both PCI and AGP are no longer put into motherboards.

[/quote]
May I ask how I figure out if its PCI or AGP?[/quote]
Usually you can tell by looking at the information about your old graphics card or look what type of slot it has in the pc’s manual.

Read full topic
item.source: What type of video card do I need?

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Payback Is A Bitch:

May I ask how I figure out if its PCI or AGP?

Its quite tricky to explain. Look at your motherboard, there should be a few white slots lined up (These are PCI slots, they house soundcards and all sorts of things).
You may also however have a brown slot which is longer than the aforementioned PCI slots. This should be an AGP slot.

Is there any way you could take a picture of the motherboard?

here are some pictures of the slots:
PCI:

and the brown slot in this picture is an AGP slot:

Read full topic

It is most likely that you motherboard is of type “AGP”. However most of todays system’s (2004+) graphics cards use a newer slot called PCI-E (pci express).

Find out what type of graphics card your motherboard takes. It’ll either be PCI or AGP, if it is PCI then I highly suggest you get a new motherboard. (PCI is not the same as earlier mentioned PCI-E). Both PCI and AGP are no longer put into motherboards.[/quote]

item.title: What type of video card do I need?
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Payback, with graphics cards you are going to need to learn that through the years motherboards have upgraded to support better graphics cards. This means that most of the high end graphics cards out today wont actually fit into your pc.

It is most likely that you motherboard is of type “AGP”. However most of todays system’s (2004+) graphics cards use a newer slot called PCI-E (pci express).

Find out what type of graphics card your motherboard takes. It’ll either be PCI or AGP, if it is PCI then I highly suggest you get a new motherboard. (PCI is not the same as earlier mentioned PCI-E). Both PCI and AGP are no longer put into motherboards.
